person_266.name: Georges-Louis Leclerc, Comte deBuffon
person_266.description: French naturalist, mathematician and cosmologist. His Histoire Naturelle, published in 1789, ran to 37 volumes. ForMemRSL.

person_699.name: WilliamHamilton
person_699.description: English diplomat, politician, antiquarian, and vulcanologist who served as the Envoy Extraordinary to the Kingdom of Naples from 1764 to 1800. FRSL.

person_820.name: ScipioneBreislak
person_820.description: Italian geologist of Swedish parentage. The vast works for the refining of sulphur in the volcanic district of Solfatara, near Naples, were erected under his direction. Professor of physics at the University of Ragusa, and subsequently at the Collegio Nazereno in Rome. He witnessed an eruption of Vesuvius in 1794 and subsequntly wrote Voyage Physique et Lithologique dans la Campagnie (1801).

person_190.name: Augustus
person_190.description: Nephew of Julius Ceasar and first Roman emperor.

person_845.name: John ThomasStanley
person_845.description: A British landowner and amateur scienticist, in 1789 he made a celebrated voyage to the Faroe Islands and Iceland with James Wright, Isaac Benners and John Baine, including the climbing of Mount Hekla. In the same year he was elected a Fellow of the Royal Society of Edinburgh.

person_300.name: Déodat Gratet deDolomieu
person_300.description: French geologist. The rock, and region of the Alps, dolomite was named after him.

person_510.name: Strabo
person_510.description: Greek geographer, philosopher, and historian who lived in Asia Minor during the transitional period of the Roman Republic into the Roman Empire.

person_164.name: JamesHall
person_164.description: Scottish baronet (1776) and MP. Chemist and geologist who supported of James Hutton's theories of uniformitarian geology. FRSL.

person_596.name: Uno vonTroil
person_596.description: Swedish traveller and the archbishop of Uppsala. He travelled to Iceland with Joseph Banks.

person_950.name: JohnBaine
person_950.description: One of the men who went with John Thomas Stanley on his Iceland expedition and climbed Mount Hekla.

place_720.name: Monte Nuovo
place_720.description: A cinder cone volcano near Naples, Italy, that first formed in the sixteenth century.

place_156.name: Naples
place_156.description: Naples is the regional capital of Campania in Italy. It is located beneath the volcano, Vesuvius.

place_1165.name: Lake Avernus
place_1165.description: A volcanic crater lake located in the Avernus crater in the Campania region of southern Italy. It is near the volcanic field known as the Phlegraean Fields and comprises part of the wider Campanian volcanic arc.

place_183.name: phlegrean fields
place_183.description: A volcano/volcanic area near Naples, Italy.

place_721.name: Pozzuoli
place_721.description: A city within the city of Naples, Italy. It is the main city of the Phlegrean Peninsula.

place_1166.name: Mount Barbaro
place_1166.description: One of the eruptive vents of the Phlegraean Fields, a volcanic field of Italy located in Campania. Also known as Monte Gauro.

place_1167.name: Calabria
place_1167.description: A region in Southern Italy. It is a peninsula bordered by Basilicata to the north, the Ionian Sea to the east, the Strait of Messina to the southwest, which separates it from Sicily, and the Tyrrhenian Sea to the west.

place_1169.name: Mount Somma
place_1169.description: A mountain located in the Province of Naples, in the Campania region of southern Italy. It has a collapsed caldera of an older volcano, with Mount Vesuvius rising up from the center.

place_169.name: Mount Vesuvius
place_169.description: Mount Vesuvius is a somma-stratovolcano located on the Gulf of Naples in Campania, Italy.

place_717.name: Lake of Agnano
place_717.description: Lake Agnano, in southern Italy, was a lake in the crater of the extinct volcano (Agnano). It was drained in 1870.

place_528.name: Solfatara Caldera
place_528.description: Solfatara di Pozzuoli is a volcanic crater near Naples. Though a dormant volcano, it emits jets of steam and sulphurous fumes.

place_718.name: Grotto del Cane
place_718.description: A cave by the Lake of Agnano, in southern Italy, that has a high concentration of carbon dioxide. Dogs were used to demonstrate this as a kind of tourist attraction, which the Shelleys refused to allow when they visited.

place_237.name: Iceland
place_237.description: A Nordic island country between the North Atlantic and Arctic Oceans.

place_1170.name: Antilles
place_1170.description: An archipelago bordered by the Caribbean Sea to the south and west, the Gulf of Mexico to the northwest, and the Atlantic Ocean to the north and east.

place_1171.name: Society Islands
place_1171.description: An archipelago in the South Pacific Ocean that includes the major islands of Tahiti, Moʻorea, Raiatea, Bora Bora and Huahine.

place_1172.name: Madeira Islands
place_1172.description: Madeira, an autonomous region of Portugal, is an archipelago comprising 4 islands off the northwest coast of Africa.

place_1044.name: Azores
place_1044.description: An autonomous region of Portugal, the Azores are an archipelago in the mid-Atlantic.

place_408.name: Lipari
place_408.description: A commune including six of seven islands of the Aeolian Islands located in the Tyrrhenian Sea off the northern coast of Sicily in southern Italy.

place_1173.name: Vulcano
place_1173.description: a small volcanic island belonging to Italy in the Tyrrhenian Sea, about 20 km (12 mi) north of Sicily and located at the southernmost end of the seven Aeolian Islands.

place_1174.name: Stromboli
place_1174.description: an island in the Tyrrhenian Sea, off the north coast of Sicily, containing Mount Stromboli, one of the four active volcanoes in Italy. It is one of the seven Aeolian Islands, a volcanic arc north of Sicily.

place_1175.name: Vulcanello
place_1175.description: A small peninsula on Vulcano with black-sand beaches & the Valle dei Mostri’s grotesque lava rock formations.

place_704.name: Bay of Naples
place_704.description: The Bay (or Gulf) of Naples is located on the south-western coast of Italy, with Naples to the north, Vesuvius to the east, and the Sorrento Peninsula to the south.

place_1176.name: São Miguel Island
place_1176.description: The biggest island in the Portuguese Azores archipelago.

place_184.name: Mount Etna
place_184.description: Mount Etna, or simply Etna, is an active stratovolcano on the east coast of Sicily, Italy.

place_1177.name: Terceira Island
place_1177.description: a volcanic island in the Azores archipelago.

place_1179.name: The Philippines
place_1179.description: an archipelagic country in Southeast Asia.

place_1180.name: Cyclades
place_1180.description: an island group in the Aegean Sea. It is likely where Davy is referring to when he says "Western Asiatic Archipelago"

place_846.name: Santorini
place_846.description: One of the Cyclades islands in the Aegean Sea. The island was devastated by a volcanic eruption in the 16th century BC.

place_1181.name: Crete
place_1181.description: The largest and most populous of the Greek islands. Davy refers to it as Candia, the name of the island under Venetian rule between the 13th and 17th centuries.

place_1191.name: Mediterranean Sea
place_1191.description: Connected to the Atlantic Ocean and almost completely surrounded by land.

place_1182.name: Cadiz
place_1182.description: An ancient port city in the Andalucia region of southwestern Spain.

place_1183.name: Skalholt
place_1183.description: a historical site in the south of Iceland, at the river Hvítá.

place_751.name: Hekla
place_751.description: Hekla is a volcano in Iceland. It has erupted many times in recorded history. 1766-68 was the eruption closest to Davy's time.

place_1184.name: Versailles
place_1184.description: The Palace of Versailles is a former royal residence commissioned by King Louis XIV located in Versailles, about 19 kilometers west of Paris, France.

place_1187.name: Rykum
place_1187.description: Icelandic valley apparently near Haukadalur, mentioned by Sir John Stanley in the Edinburgh Transactions.

place_714.name: Herculaneum
place_714.description: Herculaneum was an ancient Roman town, located in the modern-day comune of Ercolano, Campania, Italy.

place_407.name: Pompeii
place_407.description: An ancient city located in what is now the comune of Pompei near Naples in the Campania region of Italy. Pompeii was buried in volcanic ash in the Eruption of Mount Vesuvius in 79 CE.

otherwork_275.name: The Annual Register or a View of the History, Politics and Literature, for the Year 1772.
otherwork_275.author: Piero Giacomo di Toledo

otherwork_135.name: The Works of Virgil: Translated Into English Verse, by John Dryden
otherwork_135.author: Dryden's Translations of Virgil

otherwork_276.name: Viaggi alle due Sicilie ed in alcune parti dell'Appennino
otherwork_276.author: Lazzaro Spallanzani

otherwork_308.name: Observations on Mount Vesuvius, Mount Etna and other volcanos: in a series of letters, addressed to The Royal Society, from the Honourable Sir W. Hamilton K.B. F.R.S.
otherwork_308.author: William Hamilton

otherwork_279.name: The Philosophical Transactions (From the Year 1719, to the Year 1733) Abridged and Disposed under General Heads
otherwork_279.author: Thomas Foster (eds. John Eames and John Martyn)

otherwork_280.name: Philosophical Transactions of the Royal Society of London
otherwork_280.author: John Michell

otherwork_309.name: Lettres Èdifiantes et Curieuses: Mémoires du Levant [Edifying and Curious Letters: Reports from the Levant]
otherwork_309.author: Jesuit missionaries

otherwork_277.name: A Relation of a New Island which was raised up from the Bottom of the Sea on the 23rd of May 1707 in the Bay of Santorini, in the Archipelago
otherwork_277.author: Father Gorée

otherwork_228.name: Earth and Environmental Science Transactions of The Royal Society of Edinburgh
otherwork_228.author: Sir John Stanley
